newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australia stocks open firmer on bonds, results.
newsitem.headline: Australia stocks open firmer on bonds, results.

text.p: Australian stocks opened broadly higher on Friday, supported by a firmer bond market and by optimism after some strong company results on Thursday. Wall Street gave little guidance with a mere 0.17 percent gain.

"I wasn't really expecting it to open this strong. There might be some offshore buying and the market has seen some strong results," one dealer said. By 10.20 a.m. (0020 GMT), the All Ordinaries index was 20.5 points higher at 2,647.9.

Thursday's results from financial services and construction conglomerate Lend Lease and construction and contract mining group Leighton Holdings put the stocks among the winners in Monday's early trade.
Lend Lease rose 48.3 cents to A$29.45 after Thursday's full-year result, showing a 15 percent higher net profit of A$322 million and lift in final dividend to 50 cents a share.
Leighton climbed 23 cents to A$6.35. It rose nearly six percent on Thursday after announcing a special dividend of 10 cents and 32 percent higher year net profit of A$86.24 million.
"It was obviously an excellent result. They have strong future workload, which should keep them going for the next couple of years," one Sydney-based broker said of Leighton.
The banks were aided by a firmer bond market as a string of market-friendly U.S. data helped to soothe treasuries there.
"The market is taking heart from bonds as it did yesterday," said Michael Scichlau of Daiwa Securities in Melbourne.
National Australia Bank gained 20.2 cents to A$19.11, while Commonwealth Bank rose another 15 to A$16.63 after Wednesday's full year net profit of A$1.08 billion and share buyback plan.
Gold stocks rose 1.15 percent on aveage, despite weaker gold bullion. "There was some U.S. buying yesterday, and I think this continues today," one dealer said.
Normandy Mining firmed four cents to A$1.61 and Lihir Gold three cents to A$1.98.
Among the big resources companies, BHP was 20 cents firmer at A$17.42, while Rio Tinto gained 27 cents to A$21.32.
WMC recovered eight cents to trade at A$7.39 after losing 10 cents on Thursday.
Mayne Nickless climbed 21 cents or 2.6 percent to A$8.25.

Dealers pinned the gains to hopes that the government's decision to ease foreign shareholder restrictions on Optus Communications could pave the way for a quicker sale of Mayne's 25 percent stake in Optus.

"It could pave the way for a trade sale and it also brings the Optus float forward, as people are talking about early next year, whereas before they were talking about late next year," said Paul Doherty, institutional dealer at ABN AMRO Hoare Govett.
Doherty said there was talk around the market that this was worth about 40 to 50 cents to Mayne's share price.
